channel.title: Posts on TensorTales
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on TensorTales

item.title: Random Fourier Features, Part I
item.description: Random Fourier Features (RFF), in my opinion, have one of the best performance-to-cost tradeoffs in machine learning techniques today. Simple to code, cheap to fit, and unreasonably effective, they have been my bread-and-butter for small-to-medium multi-dimensional learning tasks and serve as an decent baseline for more complex systems. This post will be the first of a three part series on RFF: Post I: This post will help to build intuition of RFF through low-dimensional examples.

item.title: TensorTales
item.description: I’ve always loved machine learning. Something about it has always felt like magic. When I first learned about prediction machines, in high school, to me, they always conjured images of The Oracle of Delphi or one of those old cartoons with a group of magicians huddled around a crystal ball. Ask the right questions, cast the right spells in the right order, and the seemingly impossible, a glimpse of the future, could be yours.
